body:
We optimized range(a) and range(a,b), why not this one? 

Migrated from http://trac.cython.org/ticket/546

comment_data.body:
**scoder** commented

We do. You may just have hit one of these cases:

```
            if not isinstance(step.constant_result, (int, long)):
                # cannot determine step direction
                return node
            step_value = step.constant_result
            if step_value == 0:
                # will lead to an error elsewhere
                return node
```

Could you provide example code that doesn't work?

@robertwb changed **resolution** to `worksforme`
**status** from `new` to `closed`
commented

Hmm... it was probably the first case there.

@robertwb changed **resolution** from `worksforme` to empty
**status** from `closed` to `reopened`
commented

Actually, we can turn that second version into a c loop, it will just have to have a test that depends on the (runtime) sign of the step.

**scoder** changed **summary** from

range(a,b,c) not optimized

to

range(a,b,c) not optimized for (at compile time) unknown step value
commented

**connellybarnes** changed **_comment0** from `This defect appears to still be present in Cython 0.23.4. However, the cython.parallel.prange() command generates efficient output C code. You can see this for yourself by running the below example code through cython -a. I have asked a student to submit a patch to fix the range (3 arguments) code generation to output efficient C code, similar to what cython.parallel.prange() outputs.

'''Example code:'''

```
cimport cython.parallel

cdef main():
  cdef int i
  cdef int start
  cdef int stop
  cdef int step
  step = -4
  start = 100
  stop = 200

  for i in range(start, stop, step):
    pass

  for i in cython.parallel.prange(start, stop, step, nogil=True):
    pass
```

'''Example output C (simplified for the reader) from the cython.parallel.prange() command:'''

``````
/*  __pyx_v_start:    start index,
    __pyx_v_stop:     stop index, 
    __pyx_v_step:     step,
    __pyx_t_11:       total count of loop iterations,
    __pyx_t_10:       current loop counter,
    __pyx_v_i:        for loop variable i, calculated from counter */

__pyx_t_11 = (__pyx_v_stop - __pyx_v_start) / __pyx_v_step;
for (__pyx_t_10 = 0; __pyx_t_10 < __pyx_t_11; __pyx_t_10++)
{
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_7 + __pyx_t_9 * __pyx_t_10;
    ...
}
```` to `1452441282991940`
**_comment1** from `This defect appears to still be present in Cython 0.23.4. However, the cython.parallel.prange() command generates efficient output C code. You can see this for yourself by running the below example code through cython -a.     __pyx_t_11:       total count of loop iterations,
    __pyx_t_10:       current loop counter,

for (__pyx_t_10 = 0; __pyx_t_10 < __pyx_t_11; __pyx_t_10++)
{
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_t_7 + __pyx_t_9 \* __pyx_t_10;
    ...
}
````to`1452448702093317`

/*  __pyx_v_start:    start index,

    __pyx_t_10:       current loop counter,

for (__pyx_t_10 = 0; __pyx_t_10 < __pyx_t_11; __pyx_t_10++)
{
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_v_start + __pyx_v_step * __pyx_t_10;

```` to `1452658584726713`
commented

This defect appears to still be present in Cython 0.23.4. However, the cython.parallel.prange() command generates efficient output C code. You can see this for yourself by running the below example code through cython -a. I have asked a student to submit a patch to fix the range (3 arguments) code generation to output efficient C code, similar to what cython.parallel.prange() outputs.

'''Example code:'''

``````

cimport cython.parallel

cdef main():
  cdef int i
  cdef int start
  cdef int stop
  cdef int step
  step = -4
  start = 100
  stop = 200

  for i in range(start, stop, step):
    pass

  for i in cython.parallel.prange(start, stop, step, nogil=True):
    pass

```

'''Example output C (simplified for the reader) from the cython.parallel.prange() command:'''

```

/\*  __pyx_v_start:    start index,
    __pyx_v_stop:     stop index, 
    __pyx_v_step:     step,
    __pyx_t_11:       total count of loop iterations,
    __pyx_t_10:       current loop counter,
    __pyx_v_i:        for loop variable i, calculated from counter */

__pyx_t_11 = (__pyx_v_stop - __pyx_v_start) / __pyx_v_step;
for (__pyx_t_10 = 0; __pyx_t_10 < __pyx_t_11; __pyx_t_10++)
{
    __pyx_v_i = __pyx_v_start + __pyx_v_step \* __pyx_t_10;
    ...
}

```
```

I found a similar bug in range (not prange) in a nogil section:
```
cdef int idx, start, stop, step
with nogil:
    for idx in range(start, stop, step):
         call_some_function(idx)
```
Can you confirm this is the same ?

@kif That seems like a duplicate of https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/532
Cython doesn't support optimizing the range(a, b, c) syntax.

> Cython doesn't support optimizing the range(a, b, c) syntax.

â€¦ with a step value that is unknown at compile time.
PR #368 was a good start back in 2015 and now has conflicts. Would be great if someone could take up the existing code, rebase it and finish it up.
An easy way to get around this for now is to convert your for loop into a while loop.
The current behaviour also forbids to use `range(a, b, c)` inside `with nogil`.

title: range(a,b,c) not optimized for (at compile time) unknown step value
